title: Alternative to TS Torque
content:
hey everyone,

this board has been incredibly helpful to so many past requests, so I’m really looking forward to your replies!

I’m currently working for a client and I am looking for a squarish typeface with rounded edges. So far I am rather pleased with typesupply's »Torque« [http://vllg.com/typesupply/torque](http://web.archive.org/web/20140918080146/http:/vllg.com/typesupply/torque "http://vllg.com/typesupply/torque") – however it’s lacking a semibold between medium and bold – the bold face is a little to heavy for this design that we're aiming for.

I’m having a hard time finding proper alternatives to torque, because it is very specific, so I was hoping maybe one of you folks knows a similar typeface?

thank you in advance!
author: blackdrav

comments.content:
Is this for a business card? book cover? magazine text?

Brooklyn  
 [http://typographica.org/typeface-reviews/brooklyn/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140918080146/http:/typographica.org/typeface-reviews/brooklyn/ "http://typographica.org/typeface-reviews/brooklyn/")

Klavika  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/process\_type\_foundry/klavika\_ot/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140918080146/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/process_type_foundry/klavika_ot/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/process\_type\_foundry/klavika\_ot/")

Thanks so much for your first replies! This is for a whole corporate design, so it has to work as a logo font as well as headlines. :)

I like Brooklyn and Blender a lot, but both have sharp corners. My aim was to find that squared-sans feeling with rounded corners, similar to Torque.

If you look closely, all those sharp little edges have been rounded off, which gives it a less aggressive feel.

Typesupply created these for House Industries which might have something useable for you: [http://www.houseind.com/fonts/unitedcollection](http://web.archive.org/web/20140918080146/http:/www.houseind.com/fonts/unitedcollection "http://www.houseind.com/fonts/unitedcollection")

As mentioned earlier, Klavika fits what you are after. Also have you seen Alphaville? [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/shinn/alphaville/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140918080146/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/shinn/alphaville/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/shinn/alphaville/")

Another option is to approach Village or Typesupply directly and ask them about the weight you are after. I've down that before and found foundries are usually quite helpful.
